text.tspan: alpha = vectorAngle(a,b) == angle at corner pBefore.
where the vector length of acceleration must be below the limit!
The acceleration is possible under the limit as long as c_max <= acceleration_max * time_min.
In this case, c_max >= sin(alpha) * a
case 1b: at the acceleration limit, at the edge between possible and impossible
if the length of b is arbitrary: impossible as soon as c < sin(alpha) * a
Design document for the speed interpolation calculations for LTT.
LTT requires to compute the end velocities (blue arrows in the drawing) of polyline points in the driver.
These velocities should be as large as possible, but respect the acceleration limit.
Consider the black nominal path with two points, pBefore and p, which results in the interpolated gray machine path.
We assume all lengths and angles to be small, so that a discrete differential is a valid approximation.
range of actually possible b (speed at p)
for given a (speed before) and length of c (max. acceleration)
To fix this case for arbitrary b: Reduce a until we are at case 1b with c=sin(alpha)*a.
range of actually possible b (speed at p)
for given a (speed before) and length of c (max. acceleration)
Law of cosines: c^2 = a^2 + b^2 - 2*a*b*cos(alpha)
solve to obtain two solutions b = a * cos(alpha) +- sqrt(a^2*(cos(alpha)^2 - 1) + c^2)
where (cos^2-1) is equal to the numerically better -sin^2, so
The "+" solution is the maximum speed possible for b.
The "-" solution is the minimum speed possible for b (!!!!)
b is not arbitrary because the algorithm never increases speed, just decreases, to ensure convergence.
(and the algorithm, by design, never increases the (candidate) velocity of a point)
(the currently stored value of b is less than the "-" solution from case 3)
Solve this by going back to case 3 by reducing a until law of cosines is fulfilled:
solve c^2 = ... for a, this yields (note that the equation is symmetric w.r.t. swapping b and a)
